title: Antisymmetric - Graphical representation
course: Discrete Mathematics by Prof Sudarshan Iyengar

transcript.text: Now that we saw a couple of examples of  antisymmetric relations, I am sure it is
very clear to you people. Let me go ahead and make  a few observations about antisymmetric relations.
First observation, let me look at the graphical  representation of an antisymmetric relation.
How does it look like? So whenever (a, b) is  present; (b, a) is not present. Which means (a,
b) is present; means there is an arrow  starting from a going to b. Whenever
there is an arrow from one node to another node  the other way arrow is strictly missing. That’s
what we mean by an antisymmetric relation. However, there can be loops, you see. (a,
a) can be present but whenever (a, b) is present  (b, a), cannot be present. Just in case (b,
a) is present, then (a, b) cannot be present.  This is what we mean by an antisymmetric relation.
